No, the Human Rights Act 1998 and the Post Office Act 1969 are two separate pieces of legislation in the United Kingdom.

The Human Rights Act 1998 is an Act of Parliament that incorporated the European Convention on Human Rights into UK law, providing individuals with rights such as the right to life, freedom from torture, and freedom of expression.

The Post Office Act 1969, on the other hand, is an Act of Parliament that reorganized the postal service in the UK, establishing the Post Office as a public corporation.

There is no connection between the two Acts, and the Human Rights Act 1998 does not contain the Post Office Act 1969.
answer_with_dates:
The Human Rights Act 1998 and the Post Office Act 1969 are two separate pieces of legislation in the United Kingdom. 

The Human Rights Act 1998 came into effect on November 9, 1998, (though some provisions were brought into force on October 2, 2000) and it incorporated the European Convention on Human Rights into UK law.

The Post Office Act 1969, which came into effect on July 25, 1969, reorganized the UK postal service, making the Post Office a statutory corporation.

The Post Office Act 1969 was repealed in part by subsequent legislation, including the Postal Services Act 2000 and the Postal Services Act 2011. The Act was eventually repealed in full on June 26, 2018, by the Postal Services Act 2011 (Commencement No. 1 and Transitional Provisions) Order 2012, and the repeal was completed by the statutory instrument that implemented the final stages of the Postal Services Act 2011.

The Human Rights Act 1998 does not 'contain' the Post Office Act 1969. Instead, both are separate laws that apply to different areas of UK law and policy.
